body:
I plotted a geotiff as my background image in my pygmt figure. I then cut the region to zoom into the region of interest.

I found that this works well when the region is fully contained, but when the minimum or maximum lat/lon of the region lines up with the edge of the geotiff, then grdimage produces a weird mangled mixup of the tiff.
In the code below, examples 1-3 work well (plot entire tiff, plot region that is fully contained in tiff, plot region that is larger than tiff).  Example 5 produces strange output (plot sub-region of tiff that aligns with tiff edge); example 6 segfaults (plot another sub-region that aligns with tiff edge).

is there a chance to compare the region to the tiff extent before invoking GMT and throwing a suitable error message? 

```python
import pygmt
from pandas import read_csv
import sys
import numpy as np

proj = "C{}/{}/6i".format(-117.5, 33.5)
cm = pygmt.makecpt(cmap="etopo1", series=[0, 2818])

fig = pygmt.Figure()
fig.grdimage("exampletif.tif", projection=proj, frame=True)
fig.savefig("example1.png")

fig2 = pygmt.Figure()
fig2.grdimage("exampletif.tif", projection=proj, frame=True, region=[-117.5, -117.1, 33., 33.5])
fig2.savefig("example2.png")

fig3 = pygmt.Figure()
fig3.grdimage("exampletif.tif", projection=proj,frame=True, region=[-118.5, -117., 33., 34.5])
fig3.savefig("example3.png")

fig5 = pygmt.Figure()
fig5.grdimage("exampletif.tif", projection=proj,frame=True, region=[-118.0, -117.2, 33., 33.2])
fig5.savefig("example5.png")

fig6 = pygmt.Figure()
fig6.grdimage("exampletif.tif", projection=proj,frame=True, region=[-118.0, -117.2, 33., 33.35])
fig6.savefig("example6.png") 
```

![example1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4918736/98824297-26d51c80-2401-11eb-8b23-cd607c21a146.png)
![example2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4918736/98824295-2472c280-2401-11eb-9f29-44d3c705473f.png)
![example3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4918736/98824292-23419580-2401-11eb-9c4a-7567dc7453ee.png)
![example5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4918736/98824288-22a8ff00-2401-11eb-88ac-97532877c831.png)

comments_content.body:
Github won't let me append the Tiff file, but it's here: 

https://www.dropbox.com/s/slkec6za03nsf1n/exampletif.tif?dl=0
That is Python 3.8.6 | packaged by conda-forge , pygmt 'v0.2.0'

Hi @lermert, thanks for posting such a detailed issue with your data/code and all. Could you also post the output from `pygmt.show_versions()`? I can reproduce the segfault for fig6 with PyGMT v0.2.0 at https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/try-gmt and on my computer, but the segfault seems to only happen on the **second** run.

```python
import pygmt

proj = "C{}/{}/6i".format(-117.5, 33.5)
cm = pygmt.makecpt(cmap="etopo1", series=[0, 2818])

fig6 = pygmt.Figure()
fig6.grdimage(
    "exampletif.tif", projection=proj, frame=True, region=[-118.0, -117.2, 33.0, 33.35], V="d"
)
fig6.savefig("tmp_fig6.png")
fig6.show()
```

produces this on the first run:

![tmp_fig6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23487320/98884373-b7d8f000-24f4-11eb-8f38-9e87388f99cd.png)

This is the debugging output (using `V="d"`) on the first run:

Seems like a memory-related issue. @seisman do you know what's going on here?

Output of `pygmt.show_versions()` for reference:
```
PyGMT information:
  version: v0.2.0
System information:
  python: 3.8.6 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Oct  7 2020, 19:08:05)  [GCC 7.5.0]
  executable: /srv/conda/envs/notebook/bin/python
  machine: Linux-4.19.112+-x86_64-with-glibc2.10
Dependency information:
  numpy: 1.19.4
  pandas: 1.1.4
  xarray: 0.16.1
  netCDF4: 1.5.3
  packaging: 20.4
  ghostscript: 9.53.3
  gmt: 6.1.1
GMT library information:
  binary dir: /srv/conda/envs/notebook/bin
  cores: 6
  grid layout: rows
  library path: /srv/conda/envs/notebook/lib/libgmt.so
  padding: 2
  plugin dir: /srv/conda/envs/notebook/lib/gmt/plugins
  share dir: /srv/conda/envs/notebook/share/gmt
  version: 6.1.1
```

Might have something to do with rounding errors (similar to https://forum.generic-mapping-tools.org/t/gradient-problem-using-earth-relief-03s/787/5).

Output of `print(pygmt.grdinfo("exampletif.tif"))`:

```
exampletif.tif: Title: Grid imported via GDAL
exampletif.tif: Command: 
exampletif.tif: Remark: 
exampletif.tif: Pixel node registration used [Geographic grid]
exampletif.tif: Grid file format: gd = Import/export through GDAL
exampletif.tif: x_min: -118.000138889 x_max: -116.999861111 x_inc: 0.000277777777778 (1 sec) name: x n_columns: 3601
exampletif.tif: y_min: 32.9998611111 y_max: 34.0001388889 y_inc: 0.000277777777778 (1 sec) name: y n_rows: 3601
exampletif.tif: z_min: 0 z_max: 1495 name: z
exampletif.tif: scale_factor: 1 add_offset: 0
+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs
```

So the bounds of the grid aren't perfectly at (-118, -117, 33, 34), and maybe that is causing some problems? I tried playing around with using Degrees, Minutes, Seconds style coordinates like `region=["-118:00:00", "-117:20:00", "33:00:00", "33:36:00"]` but I think the grid's non-round bounding box region is causing issues.
Looks like an upstream GMT bug, no?

Hi, here's the show_versions() output:

`>>> pygmt.show_versions()
PyGMT information:
  version: v0.2.0
System information:
  python: 3.8.6 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Oct  7 2020, 19:08:05)  [GCC 7.5.0]
  executable: /home/lermert/code/miniconda3/envs/pyg/bin/python
  machine: Linux-5.4.0-53-generic-x86_64-with-glibc2.10
Dependency information:
  numpy: 1.19.4
  pandas: 1.1.4
  xarray: 0.16.1
  netCDF4: 1.5.3
  packaging: 20.4
  ghostscript: 9.53.3
  gmt: 6.1.1
GMT library information:
  binary dir: /home/lermert/code/miniconda3/envs/pyg/bin
  cores: 12
  grid layout: rows
  library path: /home/lermert/code/miniconda3/envs/pyg/lib/libgmt.so
  padding: 2
  plugin dir: /home/lermert/code/miniconda3/envs/pyg/lib/gmt/plugins
  share dir: /home/lermert/code/miniconda3/envs/pyg/share/gmt
  version: 6.1.1
`

It's indeed a gmt error, when I run 

`gmt grdimage -R-118/-117.5/33/33.5 labasin_maps/maps/ASTGTMV003_N33W118_dem.tif > out.ps`
then it shows exactly this behaviour. How to take it from here?

If you could report the bug upstream at https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/issues/new?assignees=&labels=&template=bug_report.md&title=, that would be great. You can mention this issue in the bug report.

In the meantime, I'm not sure if it would help but see if using https://www.pygmt.org/v0.2.0/api/generated/pygmt.grdcut.html or https://docs.generic-mapping-tools.org/latest/grdcut.html would work to cut the grid to your region of interest (and then try plotting the smaller grid with `grdimage`).

yes, thanks, I'll report upstream in the next few days. No worries, I am using simply a smaller region of interest or the built-in access to relief data, all works well! I simply tried around for a while thinking I did something wrong, so throwing an error immediately will be convenient for users.

👋 Thanks for opening your first issue here! Please make sure you filled out the template with as much detail as possible. We appreciate that you took the time to contribute!

Please make sure you read our [Contributing Guide](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and abide by our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).

The issus was first reported in the PyGMT repository, but I feel like it's a GMT bug. So I transferred the issue from PyGMT to GMT (I'm not exactly sure how "transfer issue" works, hopefully it doesn't cause any confusion.

To reproduce the issue, you can use this example file:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/slkec6za03nsf1n/exampletif.tif?dl=0

Running the following command gives:
```
gmt grdimage exampletif.tif -JC-117.5/33.5/6i -B -R-118/-117.2/33.0/33.35 -png map
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3974108/109751407-6a1fea80-7bac-11eb-81c5-8da73892b356.png)
The problem is still the well known to exist issue with reading and cutting images trough GDAL. If you convert that grid to netcdf then it works.

This is weird. Found a bug very related to this (#4898) but now this fails silently and one has to clear the sessions dir 
```
gmt grdimage exampletif.tif -JC-117.5/33.5/6i -B -R-118/-117.2/33.0/33.35 -png map
```

The only clue, very valid, comes from Julia but why is the command line GMT silent about this?

```
julia> G = gmtread("exampletif.tif", region="-118/-117.2/33.0/33.35",  grd=true);
gmtread [WARNING]: (w - x_min) must equal (NX + eps) * x_inc), where NX is an integer and |eps| <= 0.0001.
gmtread [WARNING]: w reset from -118 to -118.000138889
gmtread [WARNING]: (e - x_min) must equal (NX + eps) * x_inc), where NX is an integer and |eps| <= 0.0001.
gmtread [WARNING]: e reset from -117.2 to -117.199583333
gmtread [WARNING]: (s - y_min) must equal (NY + eps) * y_inc), where NY is an integer and |eps| <= 0.0001.
gmtread [WARNING]: s reset from 33 to 32.9995833333
gmtread [WARNING]: (n - y_min) must equal (NY + eps) * y_inc), where NY is an integer and |eps| <= 0.0001.
gmtread [WARNING]: n reset from 33.35 to 33.3501388889
gmtread [ERROR]: Computed -srcwin falls outside raster size of 3601x3601.
gmtread [ERROR]: ERROR reading file with gdalread.
gmtread [ERROR]: gmt_M_err_trap: 7
gmtread (gmt_api.c:4838(gmtapi_import_grid)): Could not open file [exampletif.tif]
[Session GMT (1)]: Error returned from GMT API: GMT_GRID_READ_ERROR (18)
[Session GMT (1)]: Error returned from GMT API: GMT_GRID_READ_ERROR (18)
ERROR: get_grid: programming error, output matrix is empty
```
Thanks for transferring the issue. Sorry I meant to do that and then got caught up in other stuff. Thanks @seisman !
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had activity in the last 90 days. It will be closed if no further activity occurs within 7 days. Thank you for your contributions.

The bug no longer occurs in the development branch, and was probably fixed by https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/pull/5819. Please reopen and/or comment if you continue to encounter issues after the next release.

title: When "region" is not fully contained within geotiff, strange thing happens
